Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Sporting Megaevents and Urban-Based Development Governance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will examine the attempts of cities to host sporting "megaevents" like the Olympics and football World Cups. In the past 20 years, as megaevents have become larger and more cities have begun to bid to host them, bidding has emerged as a significant component of global urban policymaking. Bidding to host megaevents entails large commitments of public funds (more than $570 billion total in 2011 and 2012) and sweeping policy changes to accommodate event planning and build public-private governance partnerships. Megaevent bidding now involves a host of "development" objectives that stakeholders promise to deliver. Megaevents planners historically limited their objectives to urban-scale development projects, but more recently they have claimed that megaevents can deliver transnational development outcomes like national poverty reduction, tourism development that will aid the poor, climate change mitigation, or national sustainability planning. This doctoral dissertation research project will examine why more ambitious bidding has become both possible and necessary to win a contract to host a megaevent. The doctoral student will pursue answers to the following questions: (1) Why have megaevent bidding practices become more ambitious? (2) How do policymakers, non-governmental organizations, and firms transfer and apply bidding practices between different cities? (3) What is the effect of these evolving bidding practices on the composition of stakeholders involved in development planning? To answer these questions, he will use archival materials and expert interviews to compare bids to host Olympics and football World Cups, which are the largest megaevents. He will analyze 100 such bids dating from 1991 to 2013 that sought to host events held between 2000 and 2020. The student will trace the international and historical connections in the cities' bids, including changes in the types of development and planning policy objectives pursued by bid stakeholders; funding, contracting, and knowledge sharing between cities; and the ways in which new types of bids build new types of urban-national-transnational partnerships.

Despite the large body of scholarship on megaevents, public conversations about their impacts often have been stymied by the contradictory research findings of dueling experts and their respective backers. Potential megaevent host communities need consistent, comparative information about the opportunities and challenges that cities encounter when promising planning outcomes in a bid. This project will generate comparative, transnational information and insights about the stakeholders who participate in megaevent bidding, how their policies are transferred between cities, and their role in promising "development" through megaevent planning. This information will inform citizens, policymakers, and scholars in potential megaevent hosting cities and in international event planning organizations. The study will enhance infrastructure for research and education by collaborating with megaevents research centers in the United States and Switzerland. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project analyzed the impact of sports ‘mega-events’ (like the Olympics) on urban development. Creating links between a temporary event and long term policy agendas is an important driver of urban development: mega-event planning is an opportunity to fundamentally re-envision cities at the ‘mega’ scale and to catalyze tens of billions of dollars in infrastructure investment by tying plans to a hosting deadline (e.g. using an Olympic bid to plan for new transportation infrastructure). And the impacts of these links are increasingly seen outside of cities, as mega-event planners use their urban-scale projects to facilitate national or transnational development initiatives (e.g. using an Olympic bid to direct investment toward new industries). While the general process of linking a temporary event to a local urban development agendas is well documented, less is known about these latter urban-to-national and urban-to-transnational initiatives.

The project asked why such a ‘re-scaling’ is taking place: why do mega-event planners increasingly link their urban planning projects to national and transnational policy initiatives? This question was examined using a global comparative sample of mega-event planning projects (a sample of bids to host the Olympics between 2000 and 2020, and plans for related smaller events in the same cities) and interviews with key stakeholders in the mega-events planning industry (event planning firms, and program officers in major international sports federations). Quantitative and qualitative methods were used to track the evolving scale of event-based development planning; to compare how development agendas evolved over the twenty-year sample; and map changes in the global networks of firms, governments, and sports federations which plan and finance mega-events.

The project produced three major findings: (1) National government intervention is a significant factor in re-scaling of mega-event agendas. Globally, this influence increased over the study period as government sponsors sought to link urban mega-event projects to national-scale development policies (e.g. using urban projects as pilot programs for national initiatives) or to international geopolitical agendas (e.g. using urban projects to build diplomatic prestige). (2) Urban governments also play a significant role in mega-event re-scaling. City leaders build ties with international firms and organizations to import technical knowledge into their cities and to export knowledge as a means to build diplomatic partnerships with other cities. (3) These re-scaling initiatives often produce urban development impacts even if a bid plan fails. For example, the study identified a number of ‘high frequency bidding’ cities (pursuing three or more mega-event bids within a decade) which are particularly active in using failed bids to facilitate local infrastructure investment and/or reinforce geopolitical relationships through bidding.

The project advanced knowledge in the principle discipline (Geography) by examining the broader geography of mega-events and event-based development: not only cities that host Olympics, but in the larger (and relatively under-researched) geography of failed bids and bids for smaller non-Olympic events. Much previous research has traced the impact of mega-events within individual host cities; this project enhances and extends research by mapping connections across cities. The project advanced knowledge in related interdisciplinary fields (e.g. Urban Studies and Development Studies) by assessing the impact of policy failure in cities.
